messageBody:
Robert,

Thanks for taking the time and your comments. As mentioned, this is the
first "public" exposure of some of these thoughts.

"<mdt>" syntax is used to indicate responses below.

_Marvin

Re: Automated Method Testing (AMT) Pattern
Posted by: "Robert Wenner" robert.wenner@... robertwenner
Thu May 3, 2007 9:23 pm (PST)
On Monday 30 April 2007 06:31, Marvin Toll wrote:
> If you have not been exposed to AMT - I'd appreciate any feedback on
> this definition that values brevity:
>
> http://gtcgroup.com/soaj/Road.to.SOAj.html#AMT

Some comments:

What are "hard-coded tests"? (Also: What does it mean to author them? Do you
mean write?)
<mdt> Is there a recommendation for a better term (than "hard-coded") to
describe unit tests only useful in a single context? (ex. non-generalizable
test, explicit-method test)

The text has been revised including parenthetical notation:
Writing hard-coded (single context) tests leads to ... blah blah
</mdt>

Why is the volume of test code a challenge?
<mdt> Ahh ... this question has significant significance. :-)

3,000 mm of seasonal rainfall would create havoc for a Kansas (USA) farmer,
yet the same volume works well for the rice-growing regions of Maharashtra
(India). So, is 3,000 mm of rain a "problem"???

My personal usage (pattern) of the "J2EE Core Patterns" begins with problem
perception; if a circumstance is perceived as a problem - the pattern is a
proposed solution.

My observation is that folks concerned about the "volume" of test code are
translating the observation into "complexity", "cost", "management
challenge" or perhaps general "fear uncertainty and doubt" (FUD) that this
Test Driven Development stuff is somehow just another veiled strategy for IT
to "stick-it" to the business community (remember Y2K -or- Client-Server
Computing -or- EJB 1.0?).
</mdt>

Same for effort -- why do you relate the effort on test code to the effort
on production code? Effort on test code pays back in less defects and
clearer design and other things. Would you also complain about spending
more effort on e.g. design or documentation than on production code?

<mdt> Actually, I do complain when documentation effort exceeds product
effort; it is a Project Management "smell" that priorities are misaligned.
Documentation exists to expedite getting code in production - it should be
"just enough" to add velocity to the process.

The TDD community needs to remain vigilant against zealots among us that
forget the practice exists for "expediting" (good design, defect
identification etc. etc.) ... not as an end to itself. AMT addresses those
that perceive the TDD exercise is creating more "effort" than return on
investment.

If one is content with current TDD practices and determines additional
optimization provides limited value - there is no need to pursue AMT.
</mdt>

What is the complexity in launching unit tests?
<mdt> Good catch!

The text now reads:
You want to lower the complexity threshold so developers self-select to
author unit tests.
</mdt>

What are patterned objects?
<mdt>Objects that follow a pattern - not merely the language syntax. Is
there a better way to express this? (examples = Business Objects,
Application Service Objects, Front Controller Objects etc.)
</mdt>

What are unique test maintenance points?
<mdt>Does this work better?

* Increases method reuse within the test code base.
</mdt>

Why is it a good thing if the "need for a shared understanding of
patterned object implementation definitions" (whatever that is) is
increased?
<mdt> The "J2EE Core Patterns" format lists 'Side Effect' as neither good or
bad ... actually, this is a "caution" for those using AMT the first time.

Text changed to:
* Increases the need for a consistent and detailed understanding of pattern
definitions among team members.
</mdt>

Sure one can reflectively gather all setters and getters and call them.
However, what is really gained from that?
<mdt> http://gtcgroup.com/util/TestUtil.By.Example.html </mdt>

Also, I cannot imagine how this should work for anything serious.
<mdt> This is a real dilemma for me in explaining AMT. I use the
getter/setter firing as an example since most folks understand the JavaBean
specification. At Ford Motor Company, one of our higher-order AMT base test
case methods enabled firing all CRUD operations against a DAO with a single
line of test code. The generalized test code managed transactions, verified
if the record existed, created Business Objects as required,
created/committed a new record, modified and then deleted the record etc.

Maybe I'm being lazy and not articulating the full potential of AMT by using
only the TestUtil reference implementation as an example? The AMT work done
at Ford is *not* public; however, the SOAj project will have additional
examples and higher order AMT - by the August timeframe.
</amt>

Last but not least I don't see why you call this a pattern. It does not
seem to share a lot with patterns as described by Gamma et al -- your AMT
does not even involve code, besides naming conventions?
<mdt>It appears the Wikipedia definition speaks to the notion that a "set of
rules" can be enough to constitute a "pattern".

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pattern
</mdt>

Sorry, I don't see how this "pattern" is useful at all.
<mdt> Appreciate the candor ... sounds like I need to keep working toward
articulating a compelling case for individuals to give it a try before
making a final determination.</mdt>


Cheers,
Robert
